rules.title: All work must represent the skill level of the Students on the Team
rules.description: All work must represent the skill level of the Students on the Team
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}The VEX IQ Robotics Competition and the Robotics Education & Competition Foundation (RECF) recognize that many third-party individuals and organizations produce and distribute robot designs, instructions, and/or other materials that are not under our direct control. We cannot legally regulate or restrict the activities of these external entities. However, when {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} use these resources in ways that violate the spirit and letter of the VEX Robotics Game Manual—particularly Rules <G2> and <G4>—they undermine the core mission of the program: to provide {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} with hands-on opportunities to learn, design, and innovate. While it is never our intent to punish {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}}, we can legally regulate and restrict the activities of the {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} in our competitions, and we must preserve the fairness, educational value, and integrity of the competition. Therefore, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} found to be in {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of these rules will be held accountable to the strictest interpretations of <G2> and <G4>. It is the responsibility of each {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} to be able to explain and defend the design, construction, and programming of their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} if questioned by referees, inspectors, {{ITALIC}}Event Partners{{/ITALIC}}, or judges. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should be prepared to describe their design process, justify design decisions, and demonstrate a full understanding of how their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} and code function. If a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} is unable, for any reason, to provide reasonable evidence (when requested by event staff) that their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} and code are the result of their own work, it is appropriate to assume that the {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} is in violation of <G2> and/or <G4>. Event organizers cannot reasonably know the origins of every design or independently verify whether a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} was created from scratch, purchased online, or copied from pictures of another {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} design. When questions of authenticity arise, the only direct and fair approach is to require {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} to explain and defend their work. This is not unlike academic honesty concerns in schools, and intellectual property concerns in business. By requiring {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} to defend their designs, we ensure that they are developing not only technical skills, but effective communication skills and accountability, as well. Consequences may include disqualification from matches, removal from events, and/or escalation of the investigation to VEX Robotics and the RECF for further disciplinary action, which may include sanctions up to and including removal from the program.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText:
{{ITALIC}}The VEX IQ Robotics Competition and the Robotics Education & Competition Foundation (RECF) recognize that many third-party individuals and organizations produce and distribute robot designs, instructions, and/or other materials that are not under our direct control. We cannot legally regulate or restrict the activities of these external entities. However, when {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} use these resources in ways that violate the spirit and letter of the VEX Robotics Game Manual—particularly Rules <G2> and <G4>—they undermine the core mission of the program: to provide {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} with hands-on opportunities to learn, design, and innovate. While it is never our intent to punish {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}}, we can legally regulate and restrict the activities of the {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} in our competitions, and we must preserve the fairness, educational value, and integrity of the competition. Therefore, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} found to be in {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of these rules will be held accountable to the strictest interpretations of <G2> and <G4>. It is the responsibility of each {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} to be able to explain and defend the design, construction, and programming of their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} if questioned by referees, inspectors, {{ITALIC}}Event Partners{{/ITALIC}}, or judges. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should be prepared to describe their design process, justify design decisions, and demonstrate a full understanding of how their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} and code function. If a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} is unable, for any reason, to provide reasonable evidence (when requested by event staff) that their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} and code are the result of their own work, it is appropriate to assume that the {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} is in violation of <G2> and/or <G4>. Event organizers cannot reasonably know the origins of every design or independently verify whether a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} was created from scratch, purchased online, or copied from pictures of another {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} design. When questions of authenticity arise, the only direct and fair approach is to require {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} to explain and defend their work. This is not unlike academic honesty concerns in schools, and intellectual property concerns in business. By requiring {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} to defend their designs, we ensure that they are developing not only technical skills, but effective communication skills and accountability, as well. Consequences may include disqualification from matches, removal from events, and/or escalation of the investigation to VEX Robotics and the RECF for further disciplinary action, which may include sanctions up to and including removal from the program.{{/ITALIC}}
Violation Notes: 
• {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} believed to be in {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of this rule should be reported to the Judge Advisor, {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}, or {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} for further investigation in coordination with the RSM. Based on the investigation the {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} may be removed from further {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}}, have their Robot Skills Challenge scores removed, and/or be removed from consideration from judged awards. 
• {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}} of this rule will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis, in tandem with the RECF Student Centered Policy as noted in <G2>, and the REC Foundation Code of Conduct as noted in <G1>. All reported and/or suspected <G4> {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}} should be reported to the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} during the event, and should be reported to the RECF Rules and Conduct Committee following the event.

rules.title: Each Student can only belong to one Team

rules.fullText:
Violation Note: {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} believed to be in {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of this rule should be reported to the Judge Advisor, {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}, or {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} for further investigation in coordination with the RSM.
{{ITALIC}}{{ITALIC}}Event Partners{{/ITALIC}} should bear in mind <G3>, and use common sense when enforcing this rule. It is not the intent to punish a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} who may change {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} members over the course of a season due to illness, changing schools, conflicts within a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}}, etc. {{ITALIC}}Event Partners{{/ITALIC}} and referees are not expected to keep a roster of any {{ITALIC}}Student{{/ITALIC}} who has ever been a {{ITALIC}}Driver{{/ITALIC}} for one day. This rule is intended to block any instance of loaning or sharing {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} members for the sole purpose of gaining a competitive advantage.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Hands out of the Field
rules.description: Hands out of the Field
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}If a {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Member’s{{/ITALIC}} hands extend over the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} and/or {{ITALIC}}Field Perimeter{{/ITALIC}} in a way that is safe and doesn’t contact anything in the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}}, it’s unlikely to be a {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}}. However, {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}} may still ask {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} to step back and remain completely outside the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} when necessary (e.g., for safety reasons or to reduce the chances of gameplay interference).{{/ITALIC}}

However, {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}} may still ask {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} to step back and remain completely outside the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} when necessary (e.g., for safety reasons or to reduce the chances of gameplay interference).{{/ITALIC}}

If a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} chooses to repeatedly ram full-speed into a {{ITALIC}}Field Element{{/ITALIC}}, it will be hard to convince a {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} that any damage caused was “accidental.”{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Don’t Start Before the Timer, and Stop Moving at the end of the Match
rules.description: Don’t Start Before the Timer, and Stop Moving at the end of the Match
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}It is expected that many Mix & Match {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} will have last-second “buzzer-beater” moments. The key moment occurs when the timer display shows 0:00. At many events, a buzzer sound will also play at T=0:00; however, the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} timer display takes precedence in the event of any audio discrepancies. If a {{ITALIC}}Stack{{/ITALIC}} is released from a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} before this moment, it will be allowed to finish its path and the score will be calculated once it comes to rest. However, if it is released after this moment (i.e., the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} was still moving past T=0:00) it will not count and the {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} will receive a {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} as described below. In cases where a last-second scoring attempt is “too close to call,” {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} will generally be given the “benefit of the doubt” and the score will be counted. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are advised to {{ITALIC}}Place{{/ITALIC}} and release {{ITALIC}}Stacks{{/ITALIC}} a second or two before the timer reaches zero to avoid the need for referee judgment calls.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.fullText: Violation
rules.completeText: Violation Notes: The {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} will not begin with any conditions in this rule unmet. If a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} cannot meet these conditions in a timely manner, the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} will be removed from the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} and rules <R3d> and <GG2> will apply until the situation is corrected. In most cases, they will not receive a {{ITALIC}}Disqualification{{/ITALIC}}, but they will not be permitted to play in the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}.

rules.title: Using the Load Zone
rules.description: Using the Load Zone
rules.fullText: Violation
rules.completeText:
Violation Notes: 
• {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are responsible for their own actions. {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}} that involve a Loader and {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} from opposite {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} will be given to both {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}}. 
• It is expected that most {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}} of this rule will be accidental. In accidental cases that end up being {{ITALIC}}Score Affecting{{/ITALIC}} (i.e., an illegally-{{ITALIC}}Loaded{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}} is {{ITALIC}}Connected{{/ITALIC}} to another {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}}), the first occurrence during a {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} may be treated as a {{ITALIC}}Minor Violation{{/ITALIC}} and a “final notice” that any future {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} will result in {{ITALIC}}Disqualification{{/ITALIC}} for the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. 
• Any {{ITALIC}}Score Affecting{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} during a {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}} (accidental and intentional) must be treated as a {{ITALIC}}Major Violation{{/ITALIC}}. 
• Repeated, intentional, or egregious {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}} may escalate to a {{ITALIC}}Major Violation{{/ITALIC}} at the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee’s{{/ITALIC}} discretion. One example of an egregious {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} would be placing a {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}} directly onto a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} without ever contacting the {{ITALIC}}Load Zone{{/ITALIC}}.

rules.title: One Robot per Team
rules.description: One Robot per Team
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}The intent of <R1a>, <R1b>, and <R1c> is to ensure an unambiguous level playing field for all {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are welcome (and encouraged) to improve or modify their {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} between events, or to collaborate with other {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} to develop the best possible game solution. However, a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} who brings and/or competes with two separate {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} at the same tournament has diminished the efforts of a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} who spent extra design time making sure that their one {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} can accomplish all of the game’s tasks. A multi-{{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} organization that shares a single {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} has diminished the efforts of a multi-{{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} organization that puts in the time, effort, and resources to undergo separate individual design processes and develop their own {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}}. To help determine whether a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} is a “separate {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}” or not, use the Subsystem definitions found in <R1>. Above that, use common sense as referenced in <G3>. If you can place two complete and legal {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} on a table next to each other, then they are two separate {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}}. Trying to decide if changing a pin, a wheel, or a motor constitutes a separate {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} is missing the intent and spirit of this rule.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}The intent of <R1a>, <R1b>, and <R1c> is to ensure an unambiguous level playing field for all {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are welcome (and encouraged) to improve or modify their {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} between events, or to collaborate with other {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} to develop the best possible game solution. However, a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} who brings and/or competes with two separate {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} at the same tournament has diminished the efforts of a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} who spent extra design time making sure that their one {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} can accomplish all of the game’s tasks. A multi-{{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} organization that shares a single {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} has diminished the efforts of a multi-{{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} organization that puts in the time, effort, and resources to undergo separate individual design processes and develop their own {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}}. To help determine whether a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} is a “separate {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}” or not, use the Subsystem definitions found in <R1>. Above that, use common sense as referenced in <G3>. If you can place two complete and legal {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} on a table next to each other, then they are two separate {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}}. Trying to decide if changing a pin, a wheel, or a motor constitutes a separate {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} is missing the intent and spirit of this rule.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Robots must represent the Team’s skill level
rules.description: Robots must represent the Team’s skill level
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}In VIQRC, we expect {{ITALIC}}Adults{{/ITALIC}} to teach fundamental {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} principles like linkages, drivetrains, and manipulators, then allow the {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} to determine which designs to implement and build on their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}. Similarly, {{ITALIC}}Adults{{/ITALIC}} are encouraged to teach the {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} how to code various functions involving applicable sensors and mechanisms, then have the {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} program the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} from what they have learned.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}In VIQRC, we expect {{ITALIC}}Adults{{/ITALIC}} to teach fundamental {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} principles like linkages, drivetrains, and manipulators, then allow the {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} to determine which designs to implement and build on their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}. Similarly, {{ITALIC}}Adults{{/ITALIC}} are encouraged to teach the {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} how to code various functions involving applicable sensors and mechanisms, then have the {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} program the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} from what they have learned.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Keep the power button accessible
rules.description: Keep the power button accessible
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}This rule is in place to ensure the safety of both competitors and field staff. In the event that a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} needs to be quickly powered off—whether due to a malfunction, entanglement, or other safety concern—it is crucial that the power button remains easily accessible. This allows competitors and/or field personnel to safely {{ITALIC}}Disable{{/ITALIC}} the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} without putting their hands near moving parts or other hazards inside the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}. Additionally, keeping screens and indicator lights visible helps officials diagnose issues efficiently, minimizing downtime and ensuring a smooth competition experience.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}This rule is in place to ensure the safety of both competitors and field staff. In the event that a {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} needs to be quickly powered off—whether due to a malfunction, entanglement, or other safety concern—it is crucial that the power button remains easily accessible. This allows competitors and/or field personnel to safely {{ITALIC}}Disable{{/ITALIC}} the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} without putting their hands near moving parts or other hazards inside the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}. Additionally, keeping screens and indicator lights visible helps officials diagnose issues efficiently, minimizing downtime and ensuring a smooth competition experience.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Pneumatics
rules.description: Pneumatics
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}The intent of <R18a> is to limit {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} to the air pressure stored in two Air Tanks, as well as the normal working air pressure contained in any Pneumatic Cylinders and tubing on the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} may not use other elements for the purposes of storing or generating air pressure. Using Pneumatic Cylinders or additional tubing solely for additional air storage is in {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of the spirit of this rule. Similarly, using Pneumatic Cylinders and/or tubing without an actual pneumatic system (e.g., Air Tanks and/or a Air Pump) is also in {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of the spirit of this rule.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}The intent of <R18a> is to limit {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} to the air pressure stored in two Air Tanks, as well as the normal working air pressure contained in any Pneumatic Cylinders and tubing on the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} may not use other elements for the purposes of storing or generating air pressure. Using Pneumatic Cylinders or additional tubing solely for additional air storage is in {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of the spirit of this rule. Similarly, using Pneumatic Cylinders and/or tubing without an actual pneumatic system (e.g., Air Tanks and/or a Air Pump) is also in {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of the spirit of this rule.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.fullText: Violation
rules.completeText:
Violation Notes: 
• {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}} of <GG>, <SG>, and <RSC> rules that occur during a {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} should only affect the outcome of that {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} and should not be considered when determining whether a {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} has been repeated during the event.

rules.title: Handling Robots during an Autonomous Coding Skills Match
rules.description: Handling Robots during an Autonomous Coding Skills Match
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}This rule is an explicit exception to rules <GG4> and the Violation Note for <GG10>, and may be used as part of a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} strategy for {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} are still governed by <GG4> & the Violation Note for <GG10>, especially for strategic {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}}.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}This rule is an explicit exception to rules <GG4> and the Violation Note for <GG10>, and may be used as part of a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} strategy for {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} are still governed by <GG4> & the Violation Note for <GG10>, especially for strategic {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}}.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Starting an Autonomous Coding Skills Match
rules.description: Starting an Autonomous Coding Skills Match
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}In accordance with <GG3>, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should be mindful of event schedules and set their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} up as promptly as possible. The definition of “prompt” is at the discretion of the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}, and could depend on things like how much time is left for the Skills Challenge {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}}(s) to be open, how many {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are waiting in line, etc. As a general guideline, three seconds to calibrate a Gyro Sensor would be acceptable, but three minutes to debug a program would not.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}In accordance with <GG3>, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should be mindful of event schedules and set their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} up as promptly as possible. The definition of “prompt” is at the discretion of the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}, and could depend on things like how much time is left for the Skills Challenge {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}}(s) to be open, how many {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are waiting in line, etc. As a general guideline, three seconds to calibrate a Gyro Sensor would be acceptable, but three minutes to debug a program would not.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Head Referees have ultimate and final authority on all gameplay and robot ruling decisions during the competition
rules.description: Head Referees have ultimate and final authority on all gameplay and robot ruling decisions during the competition
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}Note from the VEX GDC: The rules contained in this Game Manual are written to be enforced by human {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}}. Many rules have “black-and-white” criteria that can be easily checked. However, some rulings will rely on a judgment call from this human {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}. In these cases, {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}} will make their calls based on what they and the {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referees{{/ITALIC}} saw, what guidance is provided by their official support materials (the Game Manual and the Q&A), and most crucially, the context of the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} in question. The VEX IQ Robotics Competition does not have video replay, our {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} do not have absolute sensors to count scores, and most events do not have the resources for an extensive review conference between each {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. When an ambiguous rule results in a controversial call, there is a natural instinct to wonder what the “right” ruling “should have been,” or what the GDC “would have ruled.” This is ultimately an irrelevant question; our answer is that when a rule specifies “{{ITALIC}}Head Referee’s {{/ITALIC}}discretion” (or similar), then the “right” call is the one made by the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} in the moment. The VEX GDC designs games, and writes rules, with this expectation (constraint) in mind.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}Note from the VEX GDC: The rules contained in this Game Manual are written to be enforced by human {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}}. Many rules have “black-and-white” criteria that can be easily checked. However, some rulings will rely on a judgment call from this human {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}. In these cases, {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}} will make their calls based on what they and the {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referees{{/ITALIC}} saw, what guidance is provided by their official support materials (the Game Manual and the Q&A), and most crucially, the context of the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} in question. The VEX IQ Robotics Competition does not have video replay, our {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} do not have absolute sensors to count scores, and most events do not have the resources for an extensive review conference between each {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. When an ambiguous rule results in a controversial call, there is a natural instinct to wonder what the “right” ruling “should have been,” or what the GDC “would have ruled.” This is ultimately an irrelevant question; our answer is that when a rule specifies “{{ITALIC}}Head Referee’s {{/ITALIC}}discretion” (or similar), then the “right” call is the one made by the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} in the moment. The VEX GDC designs games, and writes rules, with this expectation (constraint) in mind.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Head Referees must be qualified
rules.description: Head Referees must be qualified

rules.title: The Drive Team Members are permitted to immediately appeal the Head Referee’s ruling
rules.description: The Drive Team Members are permitted to immediately appeal the Head Referee’s ruling
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}Some events may choose to utilize a “question box” or other designated location for discussions with {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}}. Offering a “question box” is within the discretion of the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} and/or {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}, and may act as an alternate option for asking {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} to remain in the {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}} (although all other aspects of this rule apply). However, by using this alternate location, {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} acknowledge that they are forfeiting the opportunity to use any contextual information involving the specific state of the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} at the end of the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. For example, it is impossible to appeal whether a game element was scored or not if the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} has already been reset. If this information is pertinent to the appeal, {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} should still remain in the {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}}, and relocate to the “question box” once the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} has been made aware of the concern and/or any relevant context.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}Some events may choose to utilize a “question box” or other designated location for discussions with {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}}. Offering a “question box” is within the discretion of the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} and/or {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}, and may act as an alternate option for asking {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} to remain in the {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}} (although all other aspects of this rule apply). However, by using this alternate location, {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} acknowledge that they are forfeiting the opportunity to use any contextual information involving the specific state of the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} at the end of the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. For example, it is impossible to appeal whether a game element was scored or not if the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} has already been reset. If this information is pertinent to the appeal, {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} should still remain in the {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}}, and relocate to the “question box” once the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} has been made aware of the concern and/or any relevant context.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: The Event Partner has ultimate authority regarding all non-gameplay decisions during an event
rules.description: The Event Partner has ultimate authority regarding all non-gameplay decisions during an event
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}This rule exists alongside <G1>, <S1>, and <G3>. Even though there isn’t a rule that says “do not steal from the concession stand,” it would still be within an {{ITALIC}}Event Partner’s{{/ITALIC}} authority to remove a thief from the competition.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}This rule exists alongside <G1>, <S1>, and <G3>. Even though there isn’t a rule that says “do not steal from the concession stand,” it would still be within an {{ITALIC}}Event Partner’s{{/ITALIC}} authority to remove a thief from the competition.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Be prepared for minor field variance
rules.description: Be prepared for minor field variance
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}The {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Field Elements{{/ITALIC}} are designed to be assembled and disassembled multiple times each year. {{ITALIC}}Event Partners{{/ITALIC}} store and transport {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} between events, and the individuals setting up the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} at one event may differ from those at the next. While every effort will be made to ensure minimal variance, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should expect that any {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} may be slightly different than another, and prepare accordingly. Just because something works on one {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} does not fully guarantee it will work on the next, and is not enough evidence alone to determine if a {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} is out of tolerance.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}The {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Field Elements{{/ITALIC}} are designed to be assembled and disassembled multiple times each year. {{ITALIC}}Event Partners{{/ITALIC}} store and transport {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} between events, and the individuals setting up the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} at one event may differ from those at the next. While every effort will be made to ensure minimal variance, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should expect that any {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} may be slightly different than another, and prepare accordingly. Just because something works on one {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} does not fully guarantee it will work on the next, and is not enough evidence alone to determine if a {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} is out of tolerance.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.title: Finals Match Schedule
rules.description: Finals Match Schedule
rules.fullText: {{ITALIC}}Example 1: {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 3 are tied for first place. During the tiebreaker {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}}, {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 scores 13 points and has a {{ITALIC}}Match Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} of 12 seconds. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 3 scores 13 points and has a {{ITALIC}}Match Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} of 10 seconds. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 is the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} winner. Example 2: {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 4 and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 5 are tied for third place. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 4 is the third place winner and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 5 is the fourth place winner. In this way, the lower ranked {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} must “overcome” the higher ranked {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} in order to become the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} champion.{{/ITALIC}}
rules.completeText: {{ITALIC}}Example 1: {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 3 are tied for first place. During the tiebreaker {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}}, {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 scores 13 points and has a {{ITALIC}}Match Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} of 12 seconds. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 3 scores 13 points and has a {{ITALIC}}Match Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} of 10 seconds. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 is the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} winner. Example 2: {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 4 and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 5 are tied for third place. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 4 is the third place winner and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 5 is the fourth place winner. In this way, the lower ranked {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} must “overcome” the higher ranked {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} in order to become the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} champion.{{/ITALIC}}
